Thanks for your patch!

Right off the bat, this patch seems to be completely ignoring the Redfish PrivilegeRegistry that we base our authorization model on.  Given the lack of details in your commit message as to WHY this change is being made, it's difficult to make a suggestion for next steps.
It may be better to refactor this lambda into a separate function?
Done
Please don't write lambdas more than 15 lines
Fixed. I used your example : https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61211/6/include/nbd_proxy.hpp#328
Unsafe capture of the conn object.  This needs fixed to look up from the structures.
Is this fixed with my new changes? I used this example : https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61211/6/include/nbd_proxy.hpp#328
This method is going away in other patches.  Please work to get your change rebased on top of the other websocket authorization series.
Once those changes are merged i will rebase.
Please review those other patchsets so they can merge.  Feel free to close this comment once you've reviewed.
I reviewed the patch. Please let me know anything else you want me to review.
There's no need for a lambda here.  Just call checkPermissionAndConnect directly.
Done
Please review the other two series for websockets that are in review, and rebase your patches on those.  Those series predate this patchset, and will likely merge first.
error code by reference please.
Done
This is duplicating the check already done in http/routing.hpp.  Please don't duplicate code.
The hostconsole check is specific to the obmc host console hence it is in this file.
Done

To repeat, please don't duplicate code.  Regardless of what belongs in this file or not, please don't duplicate existing authx code in individual handlers.  It makes security audits difficult to perform.
sorry, I fixed it. Please check and let me know.

I am not clear what the required permissions should be for a user to open URI /console0.  Tracing the code which appears in this review:
1. Code in http/routing.hpp handleUpgrade() calls validatePrivilege() to check if the user has Redfish privileges ConfigureComponents and ConfigureManager.
2. Code in this file, onOpen() & checkPermissionAndConnect(), checks if the user in in the hostconsole group.
Both checks must pass before the user is allowed to create the /console0 connection.

However, I understand the intention in this set of commits is to move away from the Redfish permission system, and move toward the OpenBMC privilege system.  Thus, the correct set of Redfish privileges (above) should be: "Login".  If this is done: The set of users allowed to access /console0 includes any user who is allowed to Login *and* has the special hostconsole permission.
Good catch. I talked to Gunner and he suggested to remove privileges so removed it. So now we will only check the unix group membership.
I think the permissions required to use URI /console0 should be (1) Redfish permission "Login" and OpenBMC privilege group "hostconsole", as I explained in the comments.
translated?
yes, function translateUserGroup() translates unix group to the redfish group.

Overall, this is adding a significant feature, the ability to adjust the privileges of routes based on group membership, rather than only on the Role the user is in.

While this is a great addition, it needs to be done in line with how the rest of the privilege system is constructed:

1. This patch needs to decide on a name for the "host console" privilege.
2. The routing code needs to add the "host console" privilege to the users session, likely using something like "OEMOpenBmcHostConsole".
3. A decision needs to be made if we'd like this privilege to show up in the redfish RolesCollection (probably not), and test to ensure that the desired behavior happens.
3. The routes that conincide with this new privilege need to be updated to require only that privilege, removing their old privilege level.
4. An analysis needs to be done of the possible impact to users.  If there is an impact, a meson option to retain the old behavior might be required for a period of time.

Once that is done, I see no reason to hold up this patch.

1. Privilege name is "OpenBMCHostConsole".
2. Changed the routing code to use new privilege.
3. It was decided that this privilege should not be seen on redfish roles collection.
4. Changed BMCWEB_ROUTE for obmc console to check only new privilege.
5. There is no impact for the user as new group is created and all priv-admin users are added in this new group.

"registration feature" is what I meant.

In addition, there is work going on to generalize the console endpoints, which is why hardcoding this here won't work.
Removed this code block.
Please call the appropriate functions (forwardUnauthorized) for this.  As written this bypasses a significant number of checks, and returns an incorrect error message in most of them.
Removed this block.
This call needs to be retained, and updated with the appropriate permission names.  You likely need to add a "HostConsole" permission class, that references the role.
Added privileges "OEMOpenBmcHostConsole".
I am seeing that /console0 privileges are not seen on the router side. I do not think that my changes caused this issue. It must be already there.
I have opened a github issue: https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/issues/249

I have tested my changes with fix by Ed (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/62275) and it is working as expected. When I remove the admin user from hostconsole group. console access was denied.

Hello,

I understand I'm late to the party but probably someone can still clarify please.

How is this supposed to be used with remotely authenticated users, e.g. with LDAP?
```
# busctl call xyz.openbmc_project.User.Manager /xyz/openbmc_project/user xyz.openbmc_project.User.Manager GetUserInfo s ldap_sync
a{sv} 2 "RemoteUser" b true "UserPrivilege" s "priv-admin"
```
As you can see `UserGroups` array isn't present in the reply at all in this case. This leads to a regression where previously LDAP/RADIUS/whatever-authenticated users could use SOL and now they can not (even worse, the web interface terminates the session on attempt as it gets 401 reply trying to upgrade connection to WS).

Also, why is host serial console access permission treated in a way that differs from IP KVM access? Aren't implications about the same in most scenarios? Is there a document somewhere describing the rationale behind this change?

I've been under the impression that LDAP is essentially not usable in its current form.  The fact that this has been checked in for over a year and nobody has reported LDAP issues somewhat backs that up.

I would assume that this is just a bug in phosphor-user-manager that needs fixed.

> Also, why is host serial console access permission treated in a way that differs from IP KVM access?

Because people want to treat them differently, and Redfish treats them separately.'

> Aren't implications about the same in most scenarios?

possibly.  There might be cases where the serial console is more locked down than KVM (or vice versa) so some admins might give access to one or the other.  It's probably also something to do with "Principal of least privilege".

> I've been under the impression that LDAP is essentially not usable in its current form.  The fact that this has been checked in for over a year and nobody has reported LDAP issues somewhat backs that up.

Well, I'm reporting it now. Can say after that minimal fix to webui (to assume Administrator for remote users) it's quite usable without tricks or tweaks.

> I would assume that this is just a bug in phosphor-user-manager that needs fixed.

AFAICT the LDAP support was designed under assumption that every user has just a primary group assigned and that primary group is mapped to Administrator/Operator/ReadOnly and that's it. It used to work nicely enough and it still can work but this patch I'm commenting introduced a regression.

Requiring extending not only phosphor-user-manager, bmcweb and webui-vue (for adding `GroupsAttribute`) to implement support for multiple groups but also probably the LDAP schema and actual database (at the clients'!) looks like something that breaks compatibiliity with existing installs way too much.
 
> > Also, why is host serial console access permission treated in a way that differs from IP KVM access?
> 
> Because people want to treat them differently, and Redfish treats them separately.'
> 
> > Aren't implications about the same in most scenarios?
> 
> possibly.  There might be cases where the serial console is more locked down than KVM (or vice versa) so some admins might give access to one or the other.  It's probably also something to do with "Principal of least privilege".

Then those people can please share their document called "Threat Model" so one could verify whether the implementation helps anything at all. Current way of requiring additional local group to access serial console (and not requiring anything like that for KVM so any Administrator can use it) is likely to not limit potential attacker anyhow as many modern popular setups (e.g. RHEL or Windows Server) do not even enable any control over serial by default but provide full control over KVM.

So far it looks like the gain is really dubious security-wise while regression is real...

> Well, I'm reporting it now.

Yep, that's fine.  LDAP support goes more to the fact that to my knowledge there's no way to test it, no instructions on how to set it up, or documentation for others to execute.  That's fine you're reporting it;  If your goal is to fix the bug, no need to comment here, just send the patch to fix it.  If your goal is to keep LDAP working in the long term, we either need some way to test it (think a simple script to run or something), or to have someone testing it manually periodically.


> looks like something that breaks compatibiliity with existing installs way too much.

Functionality of using Microsoft Active Directory is hard to test with a script... Also there's nothing special about it other than assigning BMC users "legacy primary POSIX group" about this setup from AD side, like any windows sysadmin should be able to assist with testing that if one wanted.

> my recommendation would be to find the bug in phosphor user manager that doesn’t expose the right groups, and just fix it.

What if there's no bug at all? It was never meant to provide a _list_ of groups. Just one single primary group. That's how the code was designed and written. There's no even good generic way to do that especially for nested groups (you have to do a recursive search over them; Microsoft AD provides a non-standard extension for the purpose).

> fwiw, this might be a case where dmtf might need to be engaged, because I don’t know how one would configure “this user has host console access” in the existing LDAP configs.

For local users Ninad provided a migration script so this change at least didn't regress that. So it looks like you're not supposed to introduce a change which would break existing configs, it should have an automatic migration path, right? But there's no way for automatic migration for LDAP config as it's not managed by BMC. So this change is wrong, it breaks valid and working usecase.

Actionable suggestion: I write a script that configures OpenLDAP in a GNU/Linux distro of your choice and sends an OpenBMC host (specific QEMU target of your choice) some Redfish requests to make it use that server for authenticating users. If that works you revert hostconsole patches (so that SOL both over WebSocket and over ssh works for an LDAP user mapped to Administrator).

Deal?
